No, I think his music is also very forward-leaning.
He takes the classic French chanson style, I guess, and he pulls it into the future.

I think it's probably best evident in probably my favorite song from all of his projects.

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
It's a familiar scenario seen almost every night on TV.
A ghastly crime has been committed, a smartly dressed man or woman walks grim-faced into the crime scene, picks up an ostensibly irrelevant object - a snow globe or a fountain pen maybe.
Turning it around at his hands the profiler says, our killer is a 35-year-old man with a limp.
Cue the local cops who now know who to look for.

TV shows like ""Criminal Minds"" and movies like ""The Silence of the Lambs"" not only celebrate the criminal profiler, they've established the profile as a legitimate, at times, almost magical tool for investigators.
In the current issue of the New Yorker magazine, Malcolm Gladwell profiles the profilers and concludes that their act consists largely of smoke and mirrors.
Malcolm Gladwell will be with us in just a moment.
A bit later, we'll meet former FBI profiler John Douglas.
You will not be surprised to hear that he disagrees with Gladwell's analysis.
Later in the hour, we'll talk to Senator Charles Grassley, who's announced an investigation into the finances of six so-called mega ministries.
Plus, the new vigilante cell phone jammers.
But first, criminal profiling.
If you have an experience with profiling or questions about how profiles are created, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
E-mail talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Malcolm Gladwell is a staff writer for the New Yorker magazine.
His article ""Dangerous Minds: Criminal Profiling Made Easy"" appears in this week's issue of the magazine.
He joins us from our bureau in New York.
Nice to have you on the program again, Malcolm.
Thank you, Neal.
And you describe this investigative tool.
Well, in this sense, crimes aren't who done it, that we become familiar with, but you describe them as he done it.

Yes, because the profiler seemed to dispense with the ordinary normal process of investigation and try and decide, just on the basis of what they see in a crime scene, who the police ought to be looking for.
And I think that the process and the procedures they use to reach those conclusions are not entirely legitimate.
Mm-hmm.
For example.
Well, there is a - the whole topology that the FBI has used arises out of a series of interviews done in the 1980s with serial killers around the country to I think the number was 33.
And John Douglas was one of those who conducted those interviews.
On the basis of those interviews, they decided that they could put all serial killers into one of two camps - the organized camp and the disorganized camp.
Later, they decided there was a third camp which was for those who are neither organized or disorganized, but that which, sort of, gives you some flavor for just how effective this topology is.
But they decided you belong to one of those two camps.
But on the basis - and they made that decision based on what they observed at the crime scene.
If it looked like there wasn't a lot of forethought, then they said you were disorganized.
If it looked like you planned it out, they said you were organized.
And from those two distinctions, they then drew a whole series of other conclusions about who you were and what you were like.
Mm-hmm.
